{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2968718,"name":"Gage Baker","username":"GageBaker","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/ac8455/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-09-20T22:09:39.161Z","cooked":"

We are planning to build a t-shirt cannon during this off season. Our current design will have a single compressor refilling a storage tank, then to two “barrel tanks” each to their own barrel in a double barrel design. We are unable to use a scuba tank or PVC for storage (due to safety and extreme heat in our area). We are hoping we can get some advice for parts, or a part list from other builds (i.e. valves, tanks, hoses, compressors…) We plan to mount this on a generic Andymark chassis.

Thanks for your help.
Team 3802

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2021-09-20T22:09:39.161Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":627,"reads":268,"readers_count":267,"score":3188.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":396075,"topic_slug":"t-shirt-cannon-parts-advice","display_username":"Gage Baker","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49488,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/t-shirt-cannon-parts-advice/396075/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":2968719,"name":"Troy Dietz","username":"troy_dietz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/troy_dietz/{size}/135768_2.png","created_at":"2021-09-20T23:00:47.549Z","cooked":"

PVC is obviously bad for storage, but keep it out of anything that will touch the pneumatic system.
Fun fact: PVC shards don’t show up on x-ray imaging.

Why would a scuba tank be problematic?

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2021-09-20T23:28:42.307Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":263,"readers_count":262,"score":187.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":396075,"topic_slug":"t-shirt-cannon-parts-advice","display_username":"Troy Dietz","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":26760,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"❤️ conflict-free COTS"},"post_url":"/t/t-shirt-cannon-parts-advice/396075/2","custom_user_title":"❤️ conflict-free COTS","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":7}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2968730,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2021-09-21T02:52:15.235Z","cooked":"

Get an old sodastream tank or a paintball tank! Exactly the same thing, other than the funky-monkey Sodastream valve… MUCH lighter and lower pressure than Scuba!

PVC = bad choice for air. Low impact strength. You can get proper air rated ABS pipe, though. Not the foam core stuff for drain waste vent from HD.

Soldered copper tubing can get you 100% custom tanks and that superior steampunk goodness

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2021-09-21T02:52:15.235Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":229,"readers_count":228,"score":80.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":396075,"topic_slug":"t-shirt-cannon-parts-advice","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/t-shirt-cannon-parts-advice/396075/3","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2968731,"name":"Chris Herzog","username":"zog","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zog/{size}/266762_2.png","created_at":"2021-09-21T03:10:17.039Z","cooked":"

My former team had started this just as things got weird in 2019. Though I’ve personally built several PVC-based golf ball shooters and T-shirt shooters, that doesn’t fly for us in the FIRST program (at least in my opinion).

Myself and some of the other mentors overseeing this effort wanted to make sure that everything we were using was commercially available and rated or actually tested and certified - it’s not a lot of money to actually get a tank hydro tested and certified for a specific pressure (think 2-3X your operating pressure). Our goal was to have a binder that could travel with the robot with data sheet for key parts as well as any third party certifications where applicable in the event that anyone wanted to see that information before allowing the robot to be used.

We’re doing a reboot of the effort leveraging paintball components where possible because it’s cheap and rated
. You can get stainless tank ends as well as various bungs for connecting fittings - our plan was to reach out to a professional certified welder (we’ve got one) and assemble a custom stainless storage tank (we’re in the SW Chicago area - lots of folks familiar with refinery and nuke plant fabrication and there is a decent amount of really good fabrication skill around here) and have it tested after assembly; the test facility will tag it and give you their test results. That carries a lot of weight if someone cares about that.

Like I said, I’ve built a bunch of PVC & modified sprinkler valve cannons but you might want to step it up from there as that home-brew stuff won’t draw a lot of respect from folks that care and know about this stuff.

[ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]"},"post_url":"/t/t-shirt-cannon-parts-advice/396075/4","custom_user_title":"Doin' robot stuff... [ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2968744,"name":"Chadfrom7226","username":"Chadfrom7226","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadfrom7226/{size}/113429_2.png","created_at":"2021-09-21T07:10:40.139Z","cooked":"

Instead of scuba tanks, look up carbon fiber paintball tanks. They make tanks bigger than 68 cubic inch. The terminology for looking up sizes/pressures is typically “68/4500” which stands for 68ci at 4500psi

Note: Scuba tanks and paintball tanks have their capacities rated differently. There is a formula somewhere that can convert between the two. Paintball tanks are liquid volume, scuba is something like scfm

For single-shot tanks, look up 5lb C02 tanks. Most have a 1-1/4 UNF thread on it that would be easy to make and allows a lot of air through

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2021-09-21T07:10:40.139Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":14,"reads":178,"readers_count":177,"score":125.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":396075,"topic_slug":"t-shirt-cannon-parts-advice","display_username":"Chadfrom7226","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20021,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/t-shirt-cannon-parts-advice/396075/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2968754,"name":"MrBasse","username":"MrBasse","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mrbasse/{size}/65032_2.png","created_at":"2021-09-21T13:39:40.886Z","cooked":"
Chadfrom7226:

For single-shot tanks, look up 5lb C02 tanks. Most have a 1-1/4 UNF thread on it that would be easy to make and allows a lot of air through

This is what we use, but a cheap adapter from any welding shop allows the use of a regulator to drop the pressure from the 500PSI starting point to something more reasonable (keep extras of those plastic gaskets, they work better than homemade gaskets). Ours typically rides right around 30-35 PSI. This avoids making something yourself that will be exposed to high pressures.

Cold weather (35-50 degrees F) is an issue with CO2 because the lines and regulator will freeze due to the high to low pressure drop and repeated firing. In warm weather we have never had an issue. 5lb CO2 refills vary, but we are currently at $14 US and it lasts for around 60 shots.

When we built one about ten years ago, we used an old fire extinguisher tank and a lawn sprinkler valve

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2021-09-21T13:53:24.114Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":20,"reads":153,"readers_count":152,"score":130.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":396075,"topic_slug":"t-shirt-cannon-parts-advice","display_username":"Mike Taylor (he/him)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":5678,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3487 Red Pride Robotics"},"post_url":"/t/t-shirt-cannon-parts-advice/396075/7","custom_user_title":"3487 Red Pride Robotics","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2968759,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2021-09-21T14:25:34.081Z","cooked":"

If you want to use a valve that won’t get questions (like a sprinkler valve will), look at McMaster 5496T11. These are designed for back pulsing air filters and will be perfect for launching T-shirts!
As for a tank, you might look at a Cheetah bead seater with an Aluminum tank. These have a 1-1/2" female pipe thread in the side (or the end for the Viper model). There are also standard small tanks that are used with the pulse valves above that have a big-ole hole in the side.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2021-09-21T14:25:34.081Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":23,"reads":150,"readers_count":149,"score":165.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":396075,"topic_slug":"t-shirt-cannon-parts-advice","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.mcmaster.com/5496T11","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"McMaster-Carr","clicks":83}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/t-shirt-cannon-parts-advice/396075/8","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2968913,"name":"Chris Herzog","username":"zog","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zog/{size}/266762_2.png","created_at":"2021-09-22T15:50:44.324Z","cooked":"
Weldingrod1:

If you want to use a valve that won’t get questions (like a sprinkler valve will), look at McMaster 5496T11 . These are designed for back pulsing air filters and will be perfect for launching T-shirts!

That’s a neat valve - for an extra $10, I’d consider going up to the 1" for more flow.

My experience in these launchers is that you need pressure but most important for a good launch is a fast acting valve. Slow valves build pressure in the launch tube too slowly - the t-shirt starts moving (slowly) as the valve first opens and if the pressure builds too slowly, the t-shirt just keeps moving (slowly but picking up speed) and before to long, you run out of barrel at which the t-shirt falls out of the end of the tube (or just has really soft launch) followed a fraction of second later by the big whoosh of your air now making it into the barrel (now empty after the T-shirt already left).

The punkin’ chunkin’ folks spend a lot of effort on very fast actuating valves for long distances for that exact reason - they want to get the pressure into the launch tube behind the projectile (while it’s still in the barrel because that’s the only time you you are pushing on it - once it reaches the end of the tube - that’s all your gonna get.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2021-09-22T15:50:44.324Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":134,"readers_count":133,"score":96.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":396075,"topic_slug":"t-shirt-cannon-parts-advice","display_username":"Chris Herzog","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":40142,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Doin' robot stuff... Zog,
Those valves are crazy fast, and exactly what you want for this application! Its a positive feedback system; really very cool internals!
I had a 2" one rigged up with no tank at all and a couple feet of pipe. I stuck that in a 5 gallon bucket of water and triggered it. The next heartbeat I was wet and the bucket was mostly empty

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2021-09-22T19:33:59.053Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":111,"readers_count":110,"score":57.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":396075,"topic_slug":"t-shirt-cannon-parts-advice","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/t-shirt-cannon-parts-advice/396075/10","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2968952,"name":"Chris Herzog","username":"zog","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zog/{size}/266762_2.png","created_at":"2021-09-22T19:46:29.157Z","cooked":"

Cool - from the exterior pic, they looked a lot like the sprinkler valve setup that uses a pressure differential one way to hold them closed and then releasing the pressure on the output side to open it up. They are super fast - no screwing or turning of anything - just a diaphragm that goes from fully closed to fully opened in the blink of an eye - like you said, perfect for this situation.

And the price is pretty decent considering this is an actual rated industrial part and not some non-rated janky plastic sprinker valve from the local hardware store.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2021-09-22T19:46:29.157Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":110,"readers_count":109,"score":52.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":396075,"topic_slug":"t-shirt-cannon-parts-advice","display_username":"Chris Herzog","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":46443,"username":"Weldingrod1","name":"Rod","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":40142,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Doin' robot stuff... Note you need to pair it with a solenoid, which is another $67… although you may be able to use a typical FRC-type solenoid instead if you have one around?

I have a 3" diaphragm dump valve from a municipal water flow system that we used for a T-shirt launcher maybe fifteen years ago. It’s rather amazing how fast they go from “fully closed” to “fully open”.

It was total overkill, and pretty fun.

The pulse valve I listed above will work with a -tiny- air valve. Its just a pilot. Kind of like the gate on an SCR. A little tickle and WHAM!
Yes, an FRC solenoid will work just fine. I tested mine with an air switch. IE, something that looks like a panel switch but switches air They come with 1/8" pipe fittings or #10-32 fittings. Super tiny.
Some/most diaphragm valves are set up internally quite a bit like the pulse valves. You just have to watch out for the ones where they intentionally slow them down to reduce water hammer. I mean, why would they do that to us???

","post_number":16,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2021-09-23T14:22:37.318Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":16,"reads":108,"readers_count":107,"score":101.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":396075,"topic_slug":"t-shirt-cannon-parts-advice","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/t-shirt-cannon-parts-advice/396075/16","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2969063,"name":"Mr V","username":"Mr_V","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mr_v/{size}/5363_2.png","created_at":"2021-09-23T15:40:14.818Z","cooked":"

Take a look at aftermarket automobile air suspension suppliers. You’ll find most of them have a wide range of tanks as well as valves. When we did one at my last team that is what we used. Specifically these Trust The Air Suspension Ride Pros; Find Exclusive Deals on Hot Rod Suspension, Lift Kits, Lowering Kits, Lambo Doors, air springs, air bags, Billet Wheel Adapters, Towing Kits, Air Shocks, Air suspension Lift Kits a pair of them leading to their own ports on the cylinder. They open and close super fast and flow a lot of air.

Our testing indicated it was the jet of air that propelled the shirt, not pressure building in the cylinder as holes in the base of the cylinder did not reduce the distance of the shot.
